facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 90 of 1953 appealed under Article 132 of the Constitution from High Court judgment dated 29th August 1952 in Original Petition No. 51 of 1952

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 90 of 1953. Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 29th August, 1952, of the High Court of TravancoreCochin at Ernakulam in Original Petition No. 51 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal by leave of the High Court of Travancore-Cochin against Full Bench order dismissing writ of certiorari application quashing government order removing appellant from service

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by leave of the High Court of Judicature of TravancoreCochin at Ernakulam is directed against an order of a Full Bench of that companyrt dismissing an application for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Government of the united State of TravancoreCochin removing the appellant from service of the State and permanently debarring him from reappointment in service.

facts.text: Petitioner entered service of erstwhile Travancore State in 1928

anchor.surface_text: The facts giving rise to the petition and the appeal are these The petitioner entered the service of the erstwhile Travancore State in the year 1928.

facts.text: Petitioner became Executive Engineer, Electricity Department in August 1937

anchor.surface_text: By promotion he became the Executive Engineer, Electricity Department in August 1937 and subsequently Electrical Engineer to Government in October 1944.

facts.text: Petitioner became Electrical Engineer to Government in October 1944

anchor.surface_text: By promotion he became the Executive Engineer, Electricity Department in August 1937 and subsequently Electrical Engineer to Government in October 1944.

facts.text: States of Travancore and Cochin integrated on 1st July 1949

anchor.surface_text: He was the Electrical Engineer to Government on the 1st July 1949 when the States of Travancore and Co- chin were integrated by a Covenant entered into between the rulers of the two States.

facts.text: Petitioner appointed officiating Chief Engineer Electricity by government order dated 11th August 1949

anchor.surface_text: By an order of the Government of the united State of Travancore-Cochin dated the 11th August 1949, he was appointed as the officiating Chief Engineer  Electricity  in the State.

facts.text: Government received complaints about senior officers in September 1949

anchor.surface_text: In or about September 1949 the Government of the 1014 united State received serious companyplaints about the companyduct and dealings of some of their senior officers and allegations of companyruption, companymunalism, etc. were made against them.

facts.text: Council of Ministers decided to take action against appellant on charges in December 1949

anchor.surface_text: In December 1949 the Council of Ministers decided to take action against the appellant on a number of charges indicated in the resolution.

facts.text: Petitioner suspended on 22nd December 1949 and handed over charge

anchor.surface_text: On the 22nd December 1949, immediately after this resolution was passed, the petitioner was informed that he was suspended from service pending enquiry and he was requested to hand over charge to Sri K. P. Sridharan Nair forthwith. The petitioner companyplied with this order and handed over charge as directed.

facts.text: Notification issued on 21st March 1950 for inquiry under Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act XI of 1122 appointing Sri K. Sankaran as Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: On the 21st March 1950 the following numberification was issued- Whereas Government are of opinion that there are sufficient grounds for making a formal and public inquiry into the truth of the imputation of misconduct of the officers mentioned below Government, under section 3 of the Travancore Public Servants  Inquiries  Act, XI of 1122, hereby companymit the said inquiry to Sri K. Sankaran, Judge, High Court, appointed Commissioner for the purpose.

facts.text: Petitioner informed of inquiry by notice on 24th April 1950

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was informed by numberice of the 24th April 1950 about this inquiry. The numberification was signed by Shri K. Menon, Chief Secretary to Government.

facts.text: Enquiry commenced on 20th May 1950, petitioner pleaded not guilty

anchor.surface_text: On the 20th May 1950 when the enquiry companymenced, the petitioner pleaded number guilty to the charges by a written statement. He was defended during the enquiry by Shri K. P. Abraham, a leading member of the Bar.

facts.text: Petitioner raised preliminary objection to Tribunal's jurisdiction based on Article 20 of Covenant, overruled

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was taken to the Tribunals jurisdiction on the basis of Article 20 of the Covenant entered into between the rulers of Tra- vancore and Cochin and it was companytended that the proceedings before the Commissioner were criminal in nature and companyld number be companymenced without the sanction of the Rajpramukh and that its absence was fatal to the enquiry. This objection was number immediately decided by the Commissioner but was ultimately overruled.

facts.text: Petitioner submitted detailed answers to charges on 22nd November 1950

anchor.surface_text: On the 22nd November 1950 the peti- tioner submitted detailed answers in writing to the various charges.

facts.text: Enquiry concluded on 27th December 1950, Commissioner report submitted 17th February 1951

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry companycluded on the 27th December 1950 and the Commissioner submitted his report to Government on the 17th February 1951.

facts.text: Show cause notice sent to petitioner on 5th July 1951 agreeing with Commissioner findings, some charges dropped

anchor.surface_text: On the 5th July 1951 the following companymunication was sent to the petitioner by the Chief Secretary to Government- I am to enclose here with a companyy of the above report and to point out that the Government agree with the findings of the Inquiring Commissioner on the several charges against you.

facts.text: Petitioner requested time extensions to show cause: till 10 Sep 1951 granted, further till 24 Sep 1951 granted, further till 31 Oct refused, did not submit explanation

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner on receipt of this numberice applied for time till the 10th September 1951 for showing cause. Time as prayed for was allowed. On the 10th September 1951 when the time granted at his own request 1017 was due to expire, he again applied for further time till the 10th November 1951. He was allowed further time till the 24th September 1951.

facts.text: Removal order issued 1st October 1951 by Rajpramukh effective from suspension date, removal notified 9th October 1951

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner having failed to avail himself of the opportunity to show cause against the action proposed against him, a draft of the proceedings relating to the enquiry was submitted to H. H. the Rajpramukh oil the 30th September 1951 and thereupon an order was issued for his removal from service from the date of suspension and debarring him from reappointment to service. The order was in proper form as having been made by H. H. the Rajpramukh and was authenticated by the Chief Secretary to Government. This order is dated the 1st October 1951.

facts.text: Public Services Commission consulted and supported proposed action before submission to Rajpramukh

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that before the papers were submitted to H. H. the Rajpramukh, the report of the Commissioner was submitted to the Public Services Commission for their companysideration. The Public Services Commission supported the action which the Government proposed to take against the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner removed from service effective 26th December 1949 on 9th October 1951

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th October 1951 the petitioner was removed from service with effect from the 26th December 1949.

facts.text: Petitioner applied for reconsideration two months after removal, rejected 25th January 1952

anchor.surface_text: Two months after the order of his removal, the petitioner submitted an ap- plication for a reconsideration of the order removing him from service. This was rejected by an order dated the 25th January 1952.

facts.text: High Court application filed 2nd June 1952 for certiorari to quash removal orders, dismissed with certificate for appeal

anchor.surface_text: On these facts and in these circumstances an application was made before the High Court of Travancore-Cocliin at Ernakulam on the 2nd June 1952 praying that the companyrt may be pleased to issue a writ in the nature of certiorari or any other writ, directions or orders calling for the records relating to the orders dated the 9th October 1951 and the 25th January 1952 and to quash the same ... The High Court negatived all the companytentions of the petitioner and dismissed the petition. It however certified that the case involved substantial questions of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution and was a fit one for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court held petitioner given reasonable opportunity under Article 311 at both stages

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the present case the petitioner had reasonable opportunity at both stages to enter upon his defence. He fully availed himself of the first opportunity and though a reasonable opportunity was also given to him at the second stage, he failed to avail himself of it and it is number open to him number to say that the requirements of clause  2  of Article 311 have number been satisfied.

facts.text: Enquiry Commissioner held some charges proved, others not

anchor.surface_text: Some of the-charges were held proved, while others were held number established.
Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 29th August, 1952, of the High Court of TravancoreCochin at Ernakulam in Original Petition No. 51 of 1952.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal's jurisdiction was valid absent sanction under Article 20 of the Covenant, as the proceedings are criminal in nature?

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was taken to the Tribunals jurisdiction on the basis of Article 20 of the Covenant entered into between the rulers of Tra- vancore and Cochin and it was contended that the proceedings before the Commissioner were criminal in nature and could not be commenced without the sanction of the Rajpramukh and that its absence was fatal to the enquiry.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner had no reasonable opportunity of showing cause against removal, was entitled to show cause twice, and whether this violated principles of natural justice?

anchor.surface_text: It was contended in the application that the applicant had no reasonable opportunity of showing cause against his removal and that he was entitled to show cause twice, once after he was found guilty and next after the punishment had been decided and that the denial of this right rendered the order of dismissal illegal and void and that it offended against the principles of natural justice.

issues.text: Whether consultation with the Public Service Commission was held as required under Article 320(3)(c)?

anchor.surface_text: It was further contended that the consultation with the Public Services Commission was not held in terms of the provisions of procedure for disciplinary action against Government servants and prescribed in Article 320, sub- section 3 c  of the Constitution of India. A number of other grounds were also taken against the order of dismissal.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner was removed by an authority subordinate to the appointing authority under Article 311(1)?

anchor.surface_text: It is not said that the petitioner was removed by an authority subordinate to that by which he was appointed. There was no occasion to raise this issue because the order of removal had been made by the Rajpramukh and was expressed according to the provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner was given a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the proposed action under Article 311(2)?

anchor.surface_text: As regards the question whether the petitioner was given reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him, the legal position in that respect and the nature of opportunity to be granted was stated by the Privy Council in the case of High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lall

issues.text: Whether the show cause notice complied with Article 166?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Thomas argued that the show cause notice was not in accordance with the provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution inasmuch as it was not expressed to have been made in the name of the Rajpramukh. As above mentioned, this notice was issued on behalf of the Government and was signed by the Chief Secretary

issues.text: Whether the enquiry at the first stage was invalid due to improper form of appointment order and non-compliance with the Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Thomas further contended that the enquiry at the first stage also was invalid and irregular. He argued that the order appointing the Enquiry Commissioner was not expressed in proper form and that the Commissioner did not conduct the enquiry in accordance with the provisions of the Act. The notification ordering an enquiry set out above was issued after the Council of Ministers had passed a resolution to that effect.

issues.text: Whether only the Maharaja could order inquiry under the Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1122?

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that under the Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1122 it was only the Maharaja who could make an order under the provisions of that Act, and that the Ministers could not take any action. Emphasis was laid on the expression Our Government in the different provisions of the Act.

issues.text: Whether proceedings required previous sanction of the Rajpramukh under Article 20 of the Covenant?

anchor.surface_text: Another point taken by Mr. Thomas was that without the sanction of the Rajpramukh the proceedings could not be started against the petitioner and reliance for this contention was placed on Article 20 of the Covenant of the united State of Travancore and Cochin.

issues.text: Whether there was non-compliance with Article 320(3)(c) consultation requirements, including for review petition?

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it was urged that there was non-compliance with the provisions of Article 320, clause 3 c of the Constitution which provides that on all disciplinary matters affecting a person serving under the Government of India or the Government of a State in a civil capacity... the State Public Service Commission... shall be consulted.

arguments.claim: Tribunal lacked jurisdiction because proceedings are criminal in nature requiring sanction of Rajpramukh under Article 20 of the Covenant

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was taken to the Tribunals jurisdiction on the basis of Article 20 of the Covenant entered into between the rulers of Tra- vancore and Cochin and it was contended that the proceedings before the Commissioner were criminal in nature and could not be commenced without the sanction of the Rajpramukh and that its absence was fatal to the enquiry.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: taken against the order of dismissal. The High Court negatived all the companyt

arguments.court_reasoning: Article 20 applies only to civil/criminal court proceedings, not departmental inquiries which merely partake of criminal character

arguments.claim: No reasonable opportunity to show cause against removal; entitled to show cause twice (after guilt and after punishment); violates natural justice

anchor.surface_text: It was contended in the application that the applicant had no reasonable opportunity of showing cause against his removal and that he was entitled to show cause twice, once after he was found guilty and next after the punishment had been decided and that the denial of this right rendered the order of dismissal illegal and void and that it offended against the principles of natural justice.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: oss-examine the witnesses examined by the Commissioner. He was able to satisfy the Enquiry Comniissioner that out of the charges levelled against him

arguments.court_reasoning: Reasonable opportunity given at both stages; petitioner availed first but failed second by own default

arguments.claim: Consultation with Public Services Commission not held as required under Article 320(3)(c)

anchor.surface_text: It was further contended that the consultation with the Public Services Commission was not held in terms of the provisions of procedure for disciplinary action against Government servants and prescribed in Article 320, sub- section 3 c  of the Constitution of India.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: on. It however certified that the case involved substantial questions of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution and was a fit one for appeal

arguments.court_reasoning: Consultation done before show cause; no need after non-response or for review petitions

arguments.claim: Show cause notice invalid as not expressed in name of Rajpramukh per Article 166

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Thomas argued that the show cause notice was not in accordance with the provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution inasmuch as it was not expressed to have been made in the name of the Rajpramukh. As above mentioned, this notice was issued on behalf of the Government and was signed by the Chief Secretary

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nquiry companyducted into the charges made against him was wholly illegal and void. In our judgment, numbere of the points urged by the learned compan

arguments.court_reasoning: Article 166 directory; substantial compliance by Chief Secretary on behalf of Government sufficient

arguments.claim: First stage enquiry invalid: appointment order not in proper form; Commissioner did not follow Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Thomas further contended that the enquiry at the first stage also was invalid and irregular. He argued that the order appointing the Enquiry Commissioner was not expressed in proper form and that the Commissioner did not conduct the enquiry in accordance with the provisions of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: lid reasons have been shown for disturbing the decision of the High Court. The question of the validity of an order of removal of a person employed in

arguments.court_reasoning: Substantial compliance; presumption resolution communicated to Rajpramukh; petitioner fully participated

arguments.claim: Only Maharaja could order inquiry under Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act 1122; Ministers could not

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that under the Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1122 it was only the Maharaja who could make an order under the provisions of that Act, and that the Ministers could not take any action. Emphasis was laid on the expression Our Government in the different provisions of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to be determined on the provisions of Article 311 of the Constitution of India. This Article is in these terms No person who is a member of a civil s

arguments.court_reasoning: 'Our Government' means Council of Ministers post-integration; Rajpramukh acts on ministers' advice

arguments.claim: Proceedings invalid without previous sanction of Rajpramukh under Article 20 of Covenant

anchor.surface_text: Another point taken by Mr. Thomas was that without the sanction of the Rajpramukh the proceedings could not be started against the petitioner and reliance for this contention was placed on Article 20 of the Covenant of the united State of Travancore and Cochin.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: taken against the order of dismissal. The High Court negatived all the companyt

arguments.court_reasoning: Article 20 limited to civil/criminal court proceedings, not departmental inquiries

arguments.claim: Non-compliance with Article 320(3)(c) consultation, including on review petition

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it was urged that there was non-compliance with the provisions of Article 320, clause 3 c of the Constitution which provides that on all disciplinary matters affecting a person serving under the Government of India or the Government of a State in a civil capacity... the State Public Service Commission... shall be consulted.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: on. It however certified that the case involved substantial questions of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution and was a fit one for appeal

arguments.court_reasoning: Consultation before show cause; unnecessary after non-response or multiple reviews

arguments.claim: Removal order complies with Article 311(1): by appointing authority (Rajpramukh)

anchor.surface_text: It is not said that the petitioner was removed by an authority subordinate to that by which he was appointed. There was no occasion to raise this issue because the order of removal had been made by the Rajpramukh and was expressed according to the provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Reasonable opportunity under Article 311(2) given at two stages; non-availment by petitioner does not violate

anchor.surface_text: As regards the question whether the petitioner was given reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him, the legal position in that respect and the nature of opportunity to be granted was stated by the Privy Council in the case of High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lall

arguments.claim: All rules of natural justice observed; fullest opportunities given

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the present case the petitioner had reasonable opportunity at both stages to enter upon his defence. He fully availed himself of the first opportunity and though a reasonable opportunity was also given to him at the second stage, he failed to avail himself of it
clauses (1) and (2) of Article 166 are directory only and non-compliance with them does not result in the order being invalid

arguments.claim: Article 20 Covenant does not apply to departmental proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Article 20 refers to the institution of civil and criminal proceedings, two well-known expressions which are terms of art and clearly relate to civil and criminal courts.

arguments.claim: Consultation under Article 320(3)(c) satisfied before show cause; no need for reviews

anchor.surface_text: In this case the Public Service Commission was in fact consulted in the matter of the action proposed against the petitioner by removing him. The Public Service Commission agreed to the proposed action.

holdings.text: The order of removal was made by the Rajpramukh, satisfying the requirement of Article 311(1) that no civil servant shall be removed by an authority subordinate to the appointing authority.

anchor.surface_text: It is not said that the petitioner was removed by an authority subordinate to that by which he was appointed. There was no occasion to raise this issue because the order of removal had been made by the Rajpramukh and was expressed according to the provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution. The requirement therefore of sub-clause (1) of Article 311 was fully satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order explicitly made by Rajpramukh and expressed per Art 166; no contention raised otherwise.

holdings.text: Petitioner was given reasonable opportunity of showing cause against proposed action under Article 311(2) at two stages: during enquiry and via show cause notice post-report.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the question whether the petitioner was given reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him, the legal position in that respect and the nature of opportunity to be granted was stated by the Privy Council in the case of High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lall and it was held that when a stage is reached when definite conclusions have been come to as to the charges, and the actual punishment to follow is provisionally determined on, that the statute gives the civil servant an opportunity for which sub-section (3) of section 240 of the Government of India Act, 1935 which corresponds to Article 311 makes provision, and that at that stage a reasonable opportunity has to be afforded to the civil servant concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council precedent; opportunity provided at inquiry (availed) and show cause (not availed due to petitioner's default).

holdings.text: Requirements of Article 311(2) satisfied as petitioner had reasonable opportunity at both stages but failed to avail second.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the present case the petitioner had reasonable opportunity at both stages to enter upon his defence. He fully availed himself of the first opportunity and though a reasonable opportunity was also given to him at the second stage, he failed to avail himself of it and it is not open to him now to say that the requirements of clause (2) of Article 311 have not been satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full participation in first stage; ample time granted for second but petitioner sought extensions and ultimately submitted nothing.

holdings.text: Show cause notice issued by Chief Secretary on behalf of Government constitutes substantial compliance with directory provisions of Article 166.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Thomas argued that the show cause notice was not in accordance with the provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution inasmuch as it was not expressed to have been made in the name of the Rajpramukh. As above mentioned, this notice was issued on behalf of the Government and was signed by the Chief Secretary ... This was in our opinion substantial compliance with the directory provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 166(1)(2) directory per SC precedent in Dattatreya case; substantial compliance test met; petitioner accepted and sought extensions.

holdings.text: All requirements of Article 311 fully complied with.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that all the requirements of Article 311 have been fully complied with in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative from above analyses on sub-clauses (1) and (2).

holdings.text: Appointment order for Enquiry Commissioner substantially complies with law; first stage enquiry valid.

anchor.surface_text: The notification ordering an enquiry set out above was issued after the Council of Ministers had passed a resolution to that effect. It must be presumed that in the normal course of business that resolution was communicated to the Rajpramukh. The order thus substantially complies with the requirements of law and in any case the effect of its not being expressed as directed by Article 166 does not vitiate the notification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption of communication to Rajpramukh; full participation by petitioner precludes challenge.

holdings.text: Under Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act 1122 post-integration, 'Our Government' means Council of Ministers; they can order inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that under the Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1122 it was only the Maharaja who could make an order under the provisions of that Act, and that the Ministers could not take any action. ... We are unable to see any force in this contention. The expression Our Government means the Maharajas Government ... After the integration ... the expression Our Government has to be construed according to the new set-up of Government and when the Council of Ministers had come into being, it is obvious that the expression our Government as adapted to fit in with the new Constitution means The Council of Ministers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual construction post-integration; Rajpramukh acts on Ministers' advice per constitutional principle.

holdings.text: Article 20 of Covenant requires sanction only for civil/criminal court proceedings, not departmental inquiries.

anchor.surface_text: Article 20 refers to the institution of civil and criminal proceedings, two well-known expressions which are terms of art and clearly relate to civil and criminal courts. ... In our judgment, Article 20 of the Covenant does not apply to proceedings which are not criminal but merely partake of that character. In our view departmental proceedings do not come within the ambit of the Article.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: 'civil or criminal proceedings' limited to court actions; concurs with High Court.

holdings.text: Consultation with Public Service Commission under Article 320(3)(c) satisfied before show cause notice; no need after non-response or for review petitions.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the Public Service Commission was in fact consulted in the matter of the action proposed against the petitioner by removing him. The Public Service Commission agreed to the proposed action. This consultation and the agreement was before the petitioner was asked to show cause ... In our opinion the consultation envisaged by Article 320 does not extend so far.

holdings.reasoning_summary: PSC consulted pre-show cause and approved; petitioner's failure to respond and reviews do not trigger re-consultation.

holdings.text: All rules of natural justice fully observed; petitioner had fullest opportunities but defaulted on second.

anchor.surface_text: After having examined all the arguments of Mr. Thomas, we are of the opinion that all the rules of natural justice were fully observed during the enquiry in this case, and the petitioner had the fullest opportunity to put in his defence both before the Enquiry Commissioner and against the action proposed to be taken against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed participation in enquiry; time extensions for show cause; own default not violation.

precedents.case_name: High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lall
precedents.cited_proposition: legal position and nature of reasonable opportunity to be granted to civil servant under provision corresponding to Article 311 when definite conclusions reached on charges and punishment provisionally determined
precedents.cited_holding: when a stage is reached when definite conclusions have been come to as to the charges, and the actual punishment to follow is provisionally determined on, that the statute gives the civil servant an opportunity [...] there was no anomaly in the view that the statute contemplates a reasonable opportunity at more than one stage

precedents.case_name: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. The State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: clauses 1 and 2 of Article 166 are directory only and non-compliance does not result in the order being invalid; substantial compliance suffices
precedents.cited_holding: clauses 1 and 2 of Article 166 are directory only and non-compliance with them does not result in the order being invalid, and that in order to determine whether there is compliance with these provisions all that is necessary to be seen is whether there has been substantial compliance with those requirements

anchor.surface_text: It is not said that the petitioner was removed by an authority subordinate to that by which he was appointed. There was no occasion to raise this issue because the order of removal had been made by the Rajpramukh and was expressed according to the provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution. The requirement therefore of sub-clause (1) of Article 311 was fully satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: After having examined all the arguments of Mr. Thomas, we are of the opinion that all the rules of natural justice were fully observed during the enquiry in this case, and the petitioner had the fullest opportunity to put in his defence both before the Enquiry Commissioner and against the action proposed to be taken against him.

In our judgment, numbere of the points urged by the learned companynsel was of a substantial character and all of them companycerned matters of mere form and numbervalid reasons have been shown for disturbing the decision of the High Court.

edges.explanation: Two-stage opportunity finding supports the concept's assertion of Article 311 requirements satisfied.
Two-stage reasonable opportunity under Article 311(2) addresses the issue of lack of reasonable opportunity and principles of natural justice including show cause.

anchor.surface_text: ved all the companytentions of the petitioner and dismissed the petition. It however certified that the case involved substantial questions of law as

edges.explanation: Holding confirms reasonable opportunity given under Article 311(2) at two stages (enquiry and show cause notice), directly addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the question whether the petitioner was given reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him, the legal position in that respect and the nature of opportunity to be granted was stated by the Privy Council in the case of High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lall and it was held that when a stage is reached when definite conclusions have been come to as to the charges, and the actual punishment to follow is provisionally determined on, that the statute gives the civil servant an opportunity for which sub-section (3) of section 240 of the Government of India Act, 1935 which corresponds to Article 311 makes provision, and that at that stage a reasonable opportunity has to be afforded to the civil servant concerned.

In our judgment, numbere of the points urged by the learned companynsel was of a substantial character and all of them companycerned matters of mere form and numbervalid reasons have been shown for disturbing the decision of the High Court.
was afforded fullest opportunity to examine and cross-examine the witnesses examined by the Commissioner. He was able to satisfy the Enquiry Comniissi

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the present case the petitioner had reasonable opportunity at both stages to enter upon his defence. He fully availed himself of the first opportunity and though a reasonable opportunity was also given to him at the second stage, he failed to avail himself of it and it is not open to him now to say that the requirements of clause (2) of Article 311 have not been satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Thomas argued that the show cause notice was not in accordance with the provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution inasmuch as it was not expressed to have been made in the name of the Rajpramukh. As above mentioned, this notice was issued on behalf of the Government and was signed by the Chief Secretary ... This was in our opinion substantial compliance with the directory provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution.

In our judgment, numbere of the points urged by the learned companynsel was of a substantial character and all of them companycerned matters of mere form and numbervalid reasons have been shown for disturbing the decision of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The notification ordering an enquiry set out above was issued after the Council of Ministers had passed a resolution to that effect. It must be presumed that in the normal course of business that resolution was communicated to the Rajpramukh. The order thus substantially complies with the requirements of law and in any case the effect of its not being expressed as directed by Article 166 does not vitiate the notification.

In our judgment, numbere of the points urged by the learned companynsel was of a substantial character and all of them companycerned matters of mere form and numbervalid reasons have been shown for disturbing the decision of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: of it applied for further time to put in his defence. He was twice granted this time. In these circumstances, the companytention of Mr. Thomas that as

edges.explanation: Holding interpreting 'Our Government' as Council of Ministers able to order inquiry addresses the issue of Maharaja's exclusive authority

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that under the Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1122 it was only the Maharaja who could make an order under the provisions of that Act, and that the Ministers could not take any action. ... We are unable to see any force in this contention. The expression Our Government means the Maharajas Government ... After the integration ... the expression Our Government has to be construed according to the new set-up of Government and when the Council of Ministers had come into being, it is obvious that the expression our Government as adapted to fit in with the new Constitution means The Council of Ministers.

In our judgment, numbere of the points urged by the learned companynsel was of a substantial character and all of them companycerned matters of mere form and numbervalid reasons have been shown for disturbing the decision of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Article 20 refers to the institution of civil and criminal proceedings, two well-known expressions which are terms of art and clearly relate to civil and criminal courts. ... In our judgment, Article 20 of the Covenant does not apply to proceedings which are not criminal but merely partake of that character. In our view departmental proceedings do not come within the ambit of the Article.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the Public Service Commission was in fact consulted in the matter of the action proposed against the petitioner by removing him. The Public Service Commission agreed to the proposed action. This consultation and the agreement was before the petitioner was asked to show cause ... In our opinion the consultation envisaged by Article 320 does not extend so far.
